div.note: Reader, picture, if you will, the lazaretto: a cramped space populated by sixteen thousand plague victims, with huts and sheds here, carts there, and people everywhere; two endless fugues of porticos, to the right and the left, teeming, overflowing, with the dead and dying, all jumbled together, on pallets or straw, while a buzzing hovered over this seemingly endless shantytown. Here and there was a coming and going, a running and stopping, a bowing and standing up of the convalescent, the delirious, and the attendants.
This was the sight that instantly greeted Renzo’s eyes and held them, transfixed and overwhelmed.

I will not attempt to describe this scene in detail, nor would the reader want me to. Following our young man on his woeful journey, we will stop where he stops, and describe enough of what he witnessed to relate what he did, and what followed.

A pathway cleared of huts and other constructions ran from where Renzo stood at the back entrance to the chapel in the middle, and from there, to the front entrance. Upon closer inspection, Renzo noticed carts moving along it, and things being removed to make space. He saw Capuchin friars and laymen directing the operation, while sending away anyone who didn’t belong there.
Fearing that he, too, would be expelled, he slipped between the huts on the right, the direction in which he happened to turn.

He continued his search from hut to hut, wherever he could set his foot, poking his head inside each one, peering at beds set up outside, studying the faces wracked with pain, contracting in spasms, or motionless in death, hoping to find the very thing he was afraid to find.
He had already walked for a while, repeating his painful examination again and again, but without finding a single woman; so he wondered if they might be in a separate area.
And he was right. But he had no idea where that area might be or how to find it.

Every now and then he ran into attendants, who were as different in appearance and dress as they were different if not opposite in the principle that gave both one and the other equal strength to perform their duties: the extinction of all compassion in one; superhuman compassion in the other.
He did not feel comfortable asking questions of either, however, to avoid running into obstacles. So he decided to continue on and try to find the women himself.
As he walked, he often had to glance away from what he saw around him, nearly blinded by the sight of so much suffering.
But where could he look, where could he rest his eyes, if not on more suffering?
The very air and sky compounded the horror of those sights, if anything indeed could.

A dense, dark fog had rolled in, making the day feel more like a stormy night. But in the center of the low, gloomy sky, the sphere of the sun broke through faintly, as if piercing a heavy veil, flickering as it radiated its heavy dead heat.

Every now and then, amid the steady drone of the jumbled multitude, a deep rumbling of thunder could be heard that seemed interrupted, hesitant. Even if you listened carefully, you could not tell where it was coming from; you might have thought it was the distant sound of carts that had screeched to a sudden halt.

In the surrounding countryside not a branch moved, not a bird alit or took flight: Only the swallow, appearing suddenly on the roof of the lazaretto, swooped down with its wings outstretched, as if to rake the yard. Alarmed by the commotion, however, it quickly soared back up and away.

This was the type of weather when, among a company of travelers, no one breaks the silence; the hunter stares at the ground as he walks, lost in thought; the peasant woman tilling the soil stops singing, unawares; the type of weather portending a storm, when nature—as if outwardly still while agitated by an inner distress—seems to oppress every living thing and bear down on every action, on leisure, on life itself.

But in that place designed for suffering and death, men who were already in the grips of disease could be seen succumbing to this new oppression. In the final throes of the disease, the pain became more excruciating, the moans grew more strangled, as hundreds and hundreds suddenly got worse. A crueler hour, perhaps, had not yet visited this place of misery.

The young man had already been walking for a while through that labyrinth of huts, in vain, when he began to discern a singular mix of wailing and bleating among the various laments, until he reached a splintered, rickety stockade from where that peculiar sound seemed to be coming.

He placed his eye against a wide crack between two boards and spotted a fenced-off area with a smattering of huts. There he saw an infirmary, or rather babies lying on little mattresses, pillows, unfolded sheets, or quilts, while wet nurses and other women fussed over them. What most drew and held his gaze were the goats that mingled about, acting as the nurses’ helpers: a hospital for the innocents, as best could be afforded by that time and place.

It was, I was saying, quite a sight to see these animals stand calmly over one baby and then another, offering their udders, or trot over to the sound of wailing, with an almost maternal instinct, and stop next to and try to position themselves above the little nursling, bleating and wagging their tails as if calling for someone to help the two of them.

Wet nurses were sitting here and there with babies held against their breasts, some so lovingly as to make the observer wonder whether they had been drawn there by the pay or by the charity that spontaneously seeks out the needy and the afflicted.
One woman, crestfallen, removed a crying infant from her weary breast and went sadly in search of an animal to take her place.
Another gazed tenderly at the little one who had fallen asleep on her breast, and, kissing it gently, went into a hut to lay it down on a little mattress.

But a third, surrendering her breast to a little stranger, stared at the sky not with an air of indifference but of distraction. What was she thinking, through that gesture, through that expression on her face, if not of a child of her own womb who had perhaps suckled on her breast not very long ago, and perhaps died upon it.
Older women attended to other chores.

One ran to pick up a crying baby and carry it to a goat that was grazing on a pile of fresh grass. She placed the baby on the udder, scolding and patting the inexperienced animal until it meekly acquiesced to the task.

One woman ran to rescue a poor infant that had been trampled by a goat that was busy nursing another baby. A third woman rocked a child back and forth in her arms, singing a lullaby, trying to coo it to sleep with songs and soft words, calling it by a name she had given the baby herself.

A Capuchin with a snow-white beard arrived carrying two shrieking babies, one in each arm, whom he had found lying next to their deceased mothers. A woman ran to take them and immediately looked around the group of women and animals to see who could take their mothers’ places.
Renzo tried to look away more than once, driven by his primary, predominant concern, only to go back and peer through the opening for a little while longer.
Finally, he pulled himself away and walked along the fence until he came upon a cluster of huts that blocked his path and forced him to turn around.
He went between the huts to try to find the fence again, so that he could follow it to the end and discover a new country.
While he was looking ahead, trying to figure out a path, a sudden, fleeting, momentary apparition caught his eye and made his heart stop.

A hundred yards ahead, he saw a Capuchin friar pass by and immediately disappear between the huts: a Capuchin who, even from this distance and at a glance, had the same gait, demeanor, and shape as Fra Cristoforo.

With all the agitation you can imagine, Renzo ran in the man’s direction. He searched the labyrinth of huts, up and down, inside and out, until, with a joy that matched his agitation, he spotted again that same form, that same friar, just ahead of him, stepping away from a kettle and walking toward a hut with a bowl in his hand. Renzo saw him sit down in the doorway and make the sign of the cross over the bowl. Then, after casting his gaze around like a man who is always alert, he started to eat.
It was indeed Padre Cristoforo.
To tell his story from the moment we lost sight of him until this encounter will only take a couple of words.

He did not leave Rimini, nor had he considered doing so, until the breakout of the plague in Milan gave him the opportunity to do something he had always wanted to do: sacrifice his life for his fellow man.
He pleaded insistently to be recalled from his current posting so he could attend to and serve the plague-stricken.
Since the man who had forced his transfer, the Count Uncle, was dead, not to mention the greater need for nurses than politicians, his request was granted without objection.
He came to Milan immediately, entered the lazaretto, and had already been there for about three months.
Renzo’s relief at finding the good friar did not last long, however, for in the very moment that he verified it was him, he could not help but notice how much he had changed.
His posture was stooped and stiff, his face gaunt and pale. He seemed utterly exhausted, his flesh broken and failing, as if the only thing holding him up was sheer willpower.
He stared at the young man who was coming toward him, who was using gestures to stand out and be recognized, since he dared not speak.
“Oh, Padre Cristoforo!” Renzo said, when he was close enough to be heard without raising his voice.
“You? Here?” asked the friar, placing his bowl on the ground and standing up.
“How are you, Padre? How are you feeling?”
“Better than many of the poor souls you see here,” answered the friar. His voice was faint, somber, altered like every other aspect of him.

Only his eyes were the same as before, if not even brighter and livelier. It was as if charity, sublimated by this extreme sacrifice, and rejoicing to feel so close to its maker, had given him a purer and more ardent flame than the one that his illness was slowly extinguishing.
“But you,” he continued, “how is it that you’re here? Why have you come to face the plague like this?”
“I’ve already had it, thank heavens.
I’ve come looking for…Lucia.”
“Lucia? Is Lucia here?”
“She is. At least I hope to God that she still is.”
“Is she your wife now?”
“Oh, dear Padre! No, she’s not my wife.
You know nothing about what happened to us?”
“No, my son. Ever since God separated me from you, I haven’t heard anything. But now that He has sent you to me, I really would like to know.
But…I thought you’d been banished?”
“So, you do know the things they did to me.”
“But you, what did you do?”
“Well, if I said that I showed good judgment that day in Milan, I would be lying, but I did not do anything wrong.”
“I believe you now, and I did before.”
“Then I can tell you everything.”
“Wait,” said the friar, and taking a few steps outside the hut, he called, “Padre Vittore!”

A few seconds later a young Capuchin appeared, whom he asked, “Can you do me a favor, Padre, and keep an eye on these poor children while I step out for a second? If anyone asks for me, please let me know.
Especially that one over there! If he shows even the smallest sign of reviving, come fetch me immediately, please.”
“Don’t worry, I will,” replied the young man. And the older man, turning to Renzo, said, “let’s go in here.
But,” he added immediately, stopping, “you look tired to me: I’m sure you need something to eat.”
“You’re right,” said Renzo, “now that you mention it, I realize I haven’t eaten all day.”

“Just a minute,” said the friar. He fetched another bowl and went to the kettle to fill it. He came back and handed it to Renzo together with a spoon. He invited the boy to sit down on the pallet that served as his bed. Then he went to a cask in the corner, drew a glass of wine, and placed it on the little table in front of his guest. Finally, he picked up his own bowl and sat down next to him.
“Oh, Padre Cristoforo!” Renzo said, “You didn’t have to go to such trouble.
You are still the same kind man.
I thank you with all my heart.”
“Don’t thank me,” said the friar, “this is food for the poor. But today you are one of them, too.
Now tell me everything I don’t know. Tell me about our poor little girl, and try to be quick about it. We haven’t got much time, and we have a lot to do, as you can see.”

Between one spoonful and the next, Renzo started to tell the story of Lucia, how she had taken refuge at the convent in Monza, and how she had been abducted…At the picture of such suffering and such danger, at the thought that he had been the one to direct the poor innocent creature to that place, the good friar gasped. But he started to breathe easier as he listened to the amazing story of how she had been freed and returned to her mother, who had found her a situation with Donna Prassede.

“Now I’ll tell you about me,” continued Renzo. And he spoke very briefly about that day in Milan, the escape, and how he had been forced to live far from Pescarenico, and then how, with the world turned upside down, he decided to take the risk and come back home. How Agnese had not been there, and how in Milan he had learned that Lucia was at the lazaretto.
“And here I am,” he concluded, “I’m here to look for her, to see if she’s alive, and if…she still wants me…because…sometimes…”
“But do you have any clue where they’ve put her?” asked the friar, “Or when she arrived?”
“No, Padre. I know nothing except that she’s here, if she is still here, I pray to God!”
“You poor boy! Where have you looked so far?”
“I’ve gone around and around, but so far, I’ve only seen men.
I figured the women must be in a separate area, but I’ve never managed to get there. If that’s true, can you show me where it is?”
“Don’t you know, my child, that men aren’t allowed in unless they have a job there?”
“Well, what would happen to me if I went there anyway?”

“The rules are fair and sacrosanct, my son. And even though the number and gravity of the problems make it difficult to observe them strictly, it still doesn’t mean that an honest man should disobey them.”

“But, Padre Cristoforo,” said Renzo, “Lucia should have been my wife. You know how we were separated. For twenty months now I’ve suffered, and I’m a patient man. I’ve come this far, taking many risks, each one worse than the last, and now…”

“I don’t know what to say,” continued the friar, responding more to his own thoughts than to Renzo’s words. “You clearly have the best intentions, and God would be pleased if everyone who enters that area behaved as I trust you will.

That same God certainly blesses you for how you have persevered in your love, and how faithful you have been in your desire and search for the woman whom He has destined for you. God is stricter than any man, but also more indulgent, and I believe He will forgive you for the unusual methods you have to use to find her.
Just remember that both you and I will have to answer for how you behave once you get there: answer not so much to men, but certainly to God.
Come.”

At this he stood, and so did Renzo. The boy heeded his words, but he had also decided, in the meantime, to abandon his earlier plan to bring up Lucia’s vow. “If he hears that, too,” he thought, “he’ll definitely make things harder for me.
Either I find her, and we’ll have time to talk about it later. Or…and in that case, what will it matter?”

As they walked to the door of the hut, which faced north, the friar continued, “Listen carefully. Padre Felice, the president of the lazaretto, is taking the few people who have recovered to finish their quarantine somewhere else.

Do you see the church there in the middle…?” Raising his shaky, bony hand, he pointed left, through the murky air, at the dome of the chapel, which towered over the miserable tents. “They will be assembling there now, and then leaving in a procession by the same gate through which you must have entered.”
“Ah! So that’s why they were clearing the path.”
“Yes. And you must have also heard the bell ring?”
“I heard it ring once.”
“That was the second bell. By the time the third bell rings, everyone will have gathered. Padre Felice will make a short speech, and then they will head out with him. At the third bell, join them.
Try to slip behind the crowd and stand to one side of the path where you can watch them pass without disturbing anyone or being noticed. And you can see…you can see…if she is among them.

If God did not wish for her to be among them, then”—and he raised his hand again, pointing to the side of the building opposite them—“over there, that part of the building and some of the yard in front is assigned to women.
You’ll see a fence dividing this section from that, but in some places there are gaps or openings, so it won’t be hard for you to slip through.
Once you’re inside, if you don’t do anything to arouse suspicion, it’s likely no one will speak to you.
But if you do run into any obstacle, just say that Padre Cristoforo from *** knows you and will answer for you.
Look for her there. Look for her with faith and…resignation.
Because, remember, you have come here searching for no small thing: You are looking for a living person in the lazaretto!
Do you know how often I’ve seen my poor charges replaced by newcomers? How many I’ve seen carried away?
How few have walked away on their own two feet?…Prepare yourself to make a sacrifice…”
“Yes, I understand,” Renzo interrupted, his eyes clouding over and his expression changing. “I understand!
I’m going: I’ll look, I’ll search in one place, then another, through the whole lazaretto, high and low…and if I don’t find her…”
“If you don’t find her?” asked the friar with a solemn, expectant air, and a look of warning.
That suggestion of doubt rekindled Renzo’s anger and extinguished the light in his eyes. “If I don’t find her, then there’s someone else I will try to find.

Whether in Milan, in his evil palace, at the ends of the earth, or in the devil’s lair, I’ll find the rat who tore us apart! If it hadn’t been for that scoundrel, then Lucia would have been my wife these twenty months. And if it had been our destiny to die, then at least we would have died together.
If he’s still alive, I’ll find him…”
“Renzo!” said the friar, grabbing him by the arm and giving him a severe look.

“And if I find him,” Renzo went on, blinded by rage, “if the plague hasn’t already brought him to justice…The days are long past when a ne’er-do-well, guarded by his bravi, can drive people to despair and laugh it off. The time has come for men to meet face-to-face. And…I’ll take justice into my own hands!”

“Shame on you!” thundered Padre Cristoforo, his voice regaining all its former power and sound. “Shame on you!” His head rose up from his chest and his cheeks colored with their former vitality. The fire in his eyes was terrifying.
“Look around you!”
With one hand, he grabbed Renzo’s arm and forcefully shook it, while sweeping the other over the vast scene of pain and suffering before them.
“Look around you! It is He who castigates!
He who judges but shall not be judged!
Who punishes and forgives!
But you, you worm crawling on the earth, you would take justice into your own hands?
Do you even know what justice is?
Go, you disgrace, leave this place!

I had hoped…yes, I had hoped that before I die, God would have given me the consolation of hearing that my poor Lucia was alive. To perhaps see her, and hear her promise that she would say a prayer for me, over there, by the common grave where I will soon be buried.
But now you have robbed me of that hope.
God did not leave her on this earth for you. And clearly you do not have the audacity to think yourself worthy of God’s consolation.
But He will have thought of her, because she is one of those souls for whom eternal consolation is reserved.
Go now, I have no more time to waste on you.”
At this he pushed Renzo’s arm away and started to head toward one of the huts of the sick.
“Padre!” Renzo said, chasing after him with an imploring gesture. “Would you send me away like this?”
“What!” the Capuchin replied in an equally stern voice.
“Do you dare expect me to take time away from the afflicted, who are waiting for me to speak to them of God’s forgiveness, to listen to your words of rage, your plans for revenge?
I listened to you when you asked for consolation and help, and for the sake of charity I interrupted my charitable work. But now you are set on revenge, so what do you want from me? Go.

I have seen victims die here with words of forgiveness on their lips. And I have seen persecutors who grieved that they could not beg their victims for forgiveness. I have wept with both. But what shall I do with you?”
“I forgive him! I really do forgive him! I forgive him for all time!” exclaimed the youth.
“Renzo,” the friar said in a grave but calmer voice, “think for a minute, and tell me how many times you have forgiven him.”
Minutes went by without an answer. Padre Cristoforo suddenly lowered his head, and in a slow somber voice, continued what he had been saying, “You know the reason I donned this habit.”
Renzo hesitated.
“You know!” the old man repeated.
“I know,” replied Renzo.
“I, too, have hated. I, who reprimanded you for a thought, for a word, when the man whom I hated with all my heart, whom I hated for so long, is a man whom I murdered.”
“Yes, but he was a bully, one of those…”
“Silence!” the friar interrupted him. “If there had been a good reason, do you really think I would have spent thirty years trying to find it?
Ah, if I could only make you feel in your heart what I have felt ever since that day, and still feel today, for the man whom I hated!
If only I could! Perhaps I cannot, but God can: I pray that He will do it!…Listen, Renzo.

He loves you better than you love yourself. You might have plotted your revenge, but He has the strength and the mercy to prevent you from carrying it out. He is granting you the grace that someone else did not deserve.
You know, and you have said many times, that He can stay the hand of a bully. But He can also stay the hand of an avenger.
Do you think that because you are poor, because you are offended, He cannot defend you from a man created in His own image?
Do you really think He will allow you to do whatever you want?
No! But do you know what you can do?
You can hate, and be lost. You can, by embracing one feeling, cast yourself beyond the blessing of God.

Because no matter what happens, no matter what fortune may hold for you, you can be sure that punishment certainly lies ahead, until your forgiveness is so true that you will never again have to say, ‘I forgive him.’ ”

“Yes, yes,” said Renzo, overcome by emotion, by confusion. “I know now that I never really have forgiven him. I know now that I have spoken like an animal and not a Christian. And now, by the grace of our Lord, yes, I forgive him with all my heart.”
“And if you were to see him?”
“I would pray to God to give me patience and to touch his heart.”
“Would you remember that God did not tell us to forgive our enemies, but to love them?
Would you remember that He loved him so much that He died for him?”
“Yes, with your help I would.”
“Good, then come with me.
You said, ‘I’ll find him,’ and you will.
Come, and you’ll see the man you so hated, whom you could and would have harmed, whose life you wanted to take.”
Taking Renzo’s hand, and gripping it as firmly as a healthy young man, he started on his way.
And Renzo followed, afraid to ask anything more.
After a few steps, the friar stopped near the opening of a hut, stared at Renzo with a mix of gravity and tenderness, and led him inside.

The first thing Renzo saw as he entered was a sick man sitting on a pile of straw; a man who was not gravely ill, and who indeed appeared to be on the verge of recovery. When the man saw Padre Cristoforo, he shook his head, as if to say no. The friar lowered his head with sadness and resignation.

Renzo, in the meantime, was looking around with restless curiosity, when he noticed three or four sick men, one of whom was on a mattress off to the side, wrapped in a bedsheet, and using a nobleman’s cloak as a blanket. He stared at him more closely. It was Don Rodrigo. Renzo took a step back, but with a firm grip the friar drew him to the edge of that dirty heap and, with his other hand, pointed at the man lying on top of it. There lay the unhappy man, unresponsive.

His eyes were wide open but vacant, his face pale and covered with black lesions, his lips black and swollen. You would have thought it was the face of a corpse, but every so often, his body would convulse violently, revealing the stubborn life still inside.
His chest lifted every so often in labored breathing. His right hand, uncovered, was pressed to his heart; his fingers, covered with lesions and black at the tips, curled inward like a claw.
“Do you see!” said the friar in a soft and solemn voice.
“It may be punishment, or it may be mercy.
What you feel now for this man who offended you is the same feeling that God—whom you, too, have offended—will have for you on the day of judgment.
Bless him, and you shall be blessed.
He has been like this for four days, showing no signs of life.

Perhaps God is ready to grant him his hour of absolution, but He wanted to hear you pray for it. Perhaps He wants both you and that innocent girl to pray for it. Or perhaps He is withholding grace until He hears your prayer, the prayer of a heart that is afflicted and resigned.
Perhaps both this man’s salvation and your own depend on your capacity for forgiveness, for compassion…for love!”
He fell silent and, joining his hands together, bowed his head and prayed. Renzo did the same.
They had been in this posture for a few moments when the bell started tolling.
Both friar and youth moved, as if in concert, and went out.
One of them asked no questions. The other made no protests. Their faces spoke for them.
“Go now,” said the friar, “go prepared to receive grace or to make a sacrifice. To praise God whatever the outcome of your search may be.
And whatever it may be, come to inform me, and we will praise him together.”
Without another word, they separated. One went back inside. The other headed to the chapel, which was no more than a hundred yards away.
